channel.title: Storing Variables While Running the Application
channel.description:
So I'm making a basic program to keep track of my budget and my money. I would like to be able input, for example, how much I spent on groceries this week through the program and have it stored without being lost once the program is closed. Would i need to create a database or something that java can pull information from and edit or can I get away with having java edit it's own code in the class files.
Again, just to clarify, I'm wanting to be able to run my program, go through the prompts and be able to enter values and have the program save them.
Thank you

More tips but instead for the visualization part :

If you’re extremely new, try use the console and make the program.

Then look at using swing with WindowBuilder for eclipse IDE. It’s a great tool that allows you to see what you’re making. Then if you feel comfortable take on a JavaFX build

item.title: Storing Variables While Running the Application
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

For something simple, you could use java.util.Properties since it can be stored to plaintext. Otherwise, maybe use JSON and find a third party API that supports serialization and deserialization to/from JSON.

item.title: Storing Variables While Running the Application
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

well for something like this you could use:

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/Serializable.html

A standard printwriter could also work (I would stick with a comma delimiter format)

Personally I would stick with either the printwriter or a database because you could easily import the file into sql or another financial application if you so desire.
